headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Nicholas Kristof is Interviewed about China; Musk Goes from Liberal Hero to Conservative Hero; Roscoe Orman is Interviewed about the Life of Bob McGrath; Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Will break it down for you.And a beloved figure on "Sesame Street" has died. Bob McGrath was an original cast member. Ahead, we're going to speak to his long-time co- star and friend who played Gordon on "Sesame Street," Roscoe Orman.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: But first, we've learned that Apple is acceleration its plans to move production out of China as protests and riots intensify in response to the country's zero Covid policies. That is according to a new report in "The Wall Street Journal." And now Apple supplier Foxconn says it is, quote, gradually restoring production capacity at that sprawling campus in central China.Anger boiled over into those violent protests at the world's largest iPhone factory. Workers protested unfair treatment, dirty living conditions, chaotic Covid rules, and much more at the factor. And video obtained by CNN shows a group of police in white hazmat suits beating workers with batons and metal rods. Analysts estimate this factory makes about half of Apple's iPhones. Let's talk about China and a lot more. We're happy to be joined this morning by "New York Times" columnist Nick Kristof. Of course, he was the "New York Time's" bureau chief in Beijing in 1989 and won a Pulitzer for his coverage of the Tiananmen democracy movement in China. So, thank you. And let's being in China. NICHOLAS KRISTOF, COLUMNIST, "THE NEW YORK TIMES": Good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You have, having covered Tiananmen, having been the bureau chief, perspective that very few do. How is what is happening in China now different?

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: So, these protests are maybe the most important since Tiananmen in 1989.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: But they are not the same at level. I mean they were in more than 300 cities and they were not repressed because there was a leadership vacuum, because there was paralysis in leadership. These have been -- you know, there was an immediate move to crush them. And China's surveillance is better than ever. I think it's hard for people to see how these take off and the way that those at Tiananmen did.But, you know, they certainly do underscore the - just the resentment that people all over China have toward the way the government --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And the bravery of some to speak out. One, you know, without a mask speaking to our Selina Wang, face, you know, covered though last week, but because they have just reached the end of the rope.

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: They've reached the boiling point.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: I think a lot of people. But the government is already arresting people, is already detaining them, is calling - it has, you know, great facial recognition systems. It's calling on people and asking them why they were out in the streets and people will pay a real price for this.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You wrote about this in your column this weekend and you wrote, China's zero Covid policy is synonymous with Xi. He owns it. The Chinese who denounce Covid lockdowns know they are criticizing Xi. So it speaks to the bravery that they have to do it.Do -- every single U.S. official on any news program is constantly asked about this and they're sort of towing the line in their statements. Antony Blinken was asked about it a lot yesterday. Would it make a difference if the U.S. came out more forcefully in support of these particular protests, not just saying we always believe in the right of people to protest?

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: I understand the caution of officials in siding with particular protesters about Covid policy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: But I think we can speak much more forcefully about the way China has repressed protests, is arresting people for peaceful expression of their views, for trying to congregate, for expressing online comments. And I think we owe it to them, owe it to democracy, we owe it to our values and we probably owe it to our interests to speak out more about that kind of repression in China, and, for that matter, in Iran as well.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Before we get to Ukraine, let's listen to what the deputy secretary of state, Wendy Sherman, said when she was asked about the potential for war. Here she was.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WENDY SHERMAN, DEPUTY SECRETARY OF STATE
utterances.sentences: I think war is potentially possible because Xi Jinping now has absolute control in China.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That was really startling to hear. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean she was talking -- the context was, she was talking about China and --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: The United States.

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: Look, there is - there's certainly been a lot of concern about a spark in the South China Sea, or even more likely in the Taiwan Strait, over the next five years. I think most people put that at maybe a 10 percent to 20 percent risk. But a real, non-zero risk. And you try to think of the most cataclysmic thing that could happen to the world over the next 10 or 20 years, that might be the most plausible tail (ph) risk that we have that would be devastating to both countries, to the world economy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And the -- to put the context more clearly, she was talking about the United States - or China and Taiwan. But we have heard what Biden has said now four times about what the United States would do, how it would respond should China invade Taiwan.

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: And we have to be, I think, very cautious because, on the one hand, the U.S. expressing a willingness to back up Taiwan does perhaps create a deterrent effect -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: So, there's a very fine balancing act that we have to pursue.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Let's talk about Ukraine. You just came back from Ukraine. Your father grew up in Ukraine. We have a photo we'd like to show of you and your dad in 2014. This is the two of you in Ukraine.And then we also have this image of you interviewing a young man who was in a bombed out apartment building. And here's what you write. At a time when the United States is so divided, Ukraine feels the opposite. There's a passionate, uplifting, leveling unity here and it is one reason Vladimir Putin may be in trouble. What did you see that we don't talk about enough, that doesn't make the headlines?

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: People in Ukraine are certainly suffering. They, you know, lost heat, they've lost electricity, in many cases they've lost water. What maybe doesn't always come through is just the passionate determination of people to resist. It is not breaking their will.I talked to a young man who, on the front lines was shot. He lost his entire left arm at the shoulder. He now has a prosthesis. He is returning to the army to fight back. And, you know, his wife initially thought he was completely crazy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: After they got blackout, she said - she understood why he wants to go back and fight with one arm.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And I have to ask you about the women. You've got nearly 60,000 women in the Ukrainian armed forces.

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: That surprised me. You know, Ukraine is, frankly, a pretty sexist traditional country. And there are almost 60,000 women who have enlisted to go fight. The Ukrainian army didn't even have standard uniforms for women and yet now they're making them. I have talked to one young woman, a 26-year-old woman whose fiance was killed on the front, and then she volunteered and enlisted. And I asked her, you know, what are you doing out here? And she said, they killed the man I love. I -- where else can I be?

utterances.speaker: PHH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Wow.

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: And it, you know, that passion on the part of women, it is going to change Ukraine, I think, the role those women are playing.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you for bringing us these stories in your reporting.Nicholas Kristof, we appreciate it very much.

utterances.speaker: KRISTOF
utterances.sentences: Good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Good to be with you.Also I want to point people to this, quickly. This annual holiday giving gift of little known organizations working to make the world a better place. We'll pull it up on the screen. It's kristofimpact.org where people can see much more. There it is. Don.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Elon Musk says he is leaning more and more to the right, and the new owner of Twitter is becoming one of the right's favorites.Here with this morning's numbers, CNN's senior data reporter Harry Enten. Hello to you. Good morning to you.

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Good morning.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, what is it, Republicans are liking this Musk Twitter takeover, right?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: They love Elon Musk.So, take a look here. This is an NBC News poll, view of Musk after buying Twitter. Republicans versus Democrats. Look at the positive on Musk among Republicans, 53 percent. Just 9 percent of Democrats have a favorable view of Musk. The vast majority, 64 percent, have a negative view of Musk. This is like the type of split that you might see of a Republican politician, maybe Donald Trump in his early days running for president. Compare this to where we were back in 2017, back when the Tesla Model 3 launched. Look here, favorable, Democrats versus Republicans.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Republicans, 37 percent, but Democrats were at 47 percent. Democrats actually viewed Musk more favorably back then. And keep in mind, of course, when it comes to electric cars, which is what Musk used to really be known for, that along with SpaceX, 65 percent of Democrats favor phasing out gas-powered cars versus just 17 percent of the GOP. So, as Musk has gone back to being, you know, more of the Twitter guy than being the electric car guy, the views have certainly changed around.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Any of these numbers explain why and how he has become so polarizing?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes, so, you know, look at social media, right? Social media companies should take an active role in monitoring speech. Fifty-five percent of Republicans disagree with that. Just 39 percent agree. Among Democrats, 83 percent agree that social media companies should take an active role in monitoring speech, which, of course, is something that Elon Musk really doesn't like.And take a look here. Internet free speech. The internet should be a free speech zone where speech should be uncensored. Sixty-five percent of Republicans agree with that, agree with Musk on that. Fifty-nine percent of Democrats disagree with that, that the internet should not be a free speech zone. So, essentially, Musk's views on how the internet should be and how free speech should be line up much more with Republicans than they do line up with Democrats. You have an interesting look on your face.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Quizzical look because it's - it's not -- I don't know if it's necessarily free speech because free speech comes with consequences. And I think some people just don't like the consequences of the - of the so-called free speech, right? ENTENtake an active role in monitoring speech. Most Republicans disagree with that. Most Democrats agree with that. I think that's really it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.Thank you, Harry.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Appreciate it.Poppy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right, coming up, we will remember the late Bob McGrath, an original cast member of "Sesame Street." His co-star, Roscoe Orman, he's here to tell us about his friend.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOB MCGRATH
utterances.sentences: Why don't we do that song about the people in your neighborhood?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Well, I'd rather not, actually.

utterances.speaker: MCGRATH
utterances.sentences: Oh, come on, it's a nice song.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Well, OK, but you start off.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm sure even Oscar would love to hear that song from that voice one more time. "Sesame Street" is a little quieter this morning as fans around the world remember one of the show's original cast members, Bob McGrath. McGrath's family confirmed that he passed away peacefully at his home on Sunday. He played Bob Johnson on "Sesame Street" going back all the way to the pilot episode in 1969. He was on the show for 47 seasons, remained a part of the "Sesame Street" family after leaving the cast in 2017. He was 90 years old and leaves behind a wife, five children and eight grandchildren.We are so happy to be joined now by co-star and longtime friend of Bob McGrath, Roscoe Orman. He played Gordon Robinson on "Sesame Street." And, Don, take it away because you were like almost in tears when he was coming up here.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: He learned Japanese, right?

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: He learned Japan - he learned to speak Japanese.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They were such fans.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: And -- yes, they were.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: They were. They loved Bob Morugoloa (ph) - or I forget how to pronounce in Japanese.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: But, yes, he was a superstar in Japan as well. But, what a loss.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What a loss, you're right. I want to talk more about him. And you think about - look, in the '60s, I grew up when "Sesame Street" was three, I think. It was three years after I was born. And then you came along with the '70s and you guys really changed people's lives. Were you and Bob -- do you think you guys were aware of that as you were doing it, because this was like brand-new television.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, yes, it didn't -- it wasn't long before we realized that "Sesame Street" was very special and something very different than most children's shows.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: They would -- I mean, they would play it in my nursery and kindergarten classes.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Do you know what my mom calls and says about the kids, she's worried that what's on TV for the kids these days isn't nearly as good as "Sesame Street." My kids are four and six. And there's too much violence, even in some of the cartoons. And she -- every day, are Sinisa and Lucca watching "Sesame Street"? Are Sinisa and Lucca - I mean that's the impact you had on Don's childhood, my childhood.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What we want for our kids. And, yes, they are, mom, my kids are watching the reruns.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. Well, you know, we raised our kids on "Sesame Street." As a matter of fact, all five of my children were on the show with us. And, you know, it was just such a wonderful, wonderful time. Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What should we know about Bob?

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, Bob was quite talented and quite, you know, a force before "Sesame Street." You know, he toured in Japan quite regularly and, yes, he -- he had quite an impact on, you know, on the show. He was, as you said, an original member of the show.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Along with Loretta Long and a few others. But, yes, he had such a wonderful, kind spirit, you know, and a great talent as a singer.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: And he was -- he was a member of "Sing Along with Mitch." I don't know if that -- that goes way before your time, I'm sure.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: One of the things he said in -- a few years ago that was at -- one of his main takeaways from the show is how important it is -- these are his words -- "Sesame Street" taught him how important it is to listen, to really listen carefully to what your children have to say.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They're wise, aren't they, our kids?

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, they are. They are. Yes, there had never been a show that targeted that kind of, you know, information or education for preschoolers, you know. So, it was groundbreaking. And I was - I just couldn't believe that I was able to join the company and be a long -- long-time member of the show.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What a great fortune, right? I mean, yes.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. Just incredible. I had no idea that I would be on a children's show. You know, I had done some other -- quite a few other kinds of performance that were not for kids. But "Sesame Street" was very special. There was nothing like it ever before.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, Roscoe, we're so happy that you could come in.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And to remember your friend, Bob McGrath.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Ninety years old.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Ninety years old.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: One of the originals to "Sesame Street."

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What a life.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And thank you for what you do.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: ORMAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you for - for having me.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, this is just into CNN. Netflix just released a new "Harry and Meghan" documentary trailer. Here it is.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: There's a hierarchy of the family. You know, there's leaking, but there's also planting of stories.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: There was a war against Meghan to suit other people's agendas. UNIDENTIFIED MALE

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY
utterances.sentences: It's a dirty game.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Hmm.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: The trailer also said that there was pain and suffering, women marrying into this institution Harry continues to say that he didn't want history to repeat itself.What did you think?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Obviously we're -- well, history of losing his mother, Diana, and all that she faced.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.  Yes. It's -- people are so interested in them. I think they - obviously, I know they've garnered more attention --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Than?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They're so -- it's brave to put yourself out there like that. I can't wait to see it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK. Thanks.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's good to see.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We'll be back here with Kaitlan. We feel like we're missing an appendage. Kaitlan, come back.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: See you all tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You can see her. She'll be on the air tomorrow.You guys have a great day. Thanks for joining us.
